text: Agree with Kendall. It reads as one of those intensifiers like "In fact," "However," etc. Every once in a while, those words can serve a purpose, but most of the time, they can be omitted.

text: *Do you use third-party content in your company newsletter or social feeds?* I like the idea of standing on the shoulders of giants, but on my team, I feel l have to fight the click leak argument: "_Why would we link to another site when we can link to ours? Doesn't that risk losing a potential opportunity or conversion_?"

I like the idea of standing on the shoulders of giants, but on my team, I feel l have to fight the click leak argument: "
Why would we link to another site when we can link to ours? Doesn't that risk losing a potential opportunity or conversion

text:
totally agree with everything said previously - we've worked with some big SaaS companies that do this at scale, taking the same core article structure and making niche-specific versions

there's still a LOT a great writer can do to differentiate each version. I would definitely recommend running interviews with an SME in each industry to find:

• the right framing and terminology for the problem (what most companies would call "document management," a legal company calls "matter management")
• industry-specific examples and case studies
• industry-specific publications, research reports and newsletters to reference for credibility
• etc

elements.text:

there's still a LOT a great writer can do to differentiate each version. I would definitely recommend running interviews with an SME in each industry to find:
the right framing and terminology for the problem (what most companies would call "document management," a legal company calls "matter management")
industry-specific examples and case studies
industry-specific publications, research reports and newsletters to reference for credibility
etc

text: Because you’re building an audience who care about a thing, and you’re not the only source of the thing! Flip it, you are using the hard work of others to help you build your following and craft and test your messaging

text: Hey, I need some advice from the content and SEO experts. I've been contributing blogs for a business for over a year. I'm not responsible for performance because it's completely in the hands of the business, I just suggest topics and send them the content. I checked it out in UberSuggest and only one blog from this January ranks for a decent-volume keyword. One other ranks for some zero volume keywords. What are the first things you would look at to see why it isn't performing? I've already had them change the layout and readability of their blog because it was terrible. But they won't make any significant changes. Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey, I need some advice from the content and SEO experts. I've been contributing blogs for a business for over a year. I'm not responsible for performance because it's completely in the hands of the business, I just suggest topics and send them the content. I checked it out in UberSuggest and only one blog from this January ranks for a decent-volume keyword. One other ranks for some zero volume keywords. What are the first things you would look at to see why it isn't performing? I've already had them change the layout and readability of their blog because it was terrible. But they won't make any significant changes. Thanks

text: Love the idea of putting the emphasis on the goal of development rather than tactical conversion.

elements.text: Love the idea of putting the emphasis on the goal of development rather than tactical conversion.

text: Are they optimized for a specific keyword?

elements.text: Are they optimized for a specific keyword?

text:
1. Completely ignore Ubersuggest. It's worthless since it was acquired and (hot take) is just there to acquire links and be a personal brand tool.
2. What's the blog? Happy to do a quick screenshot from Ahrefs or SEMrush for ya.
3. LOTS of things make it perform better is search: the content on the page, the topic you're writing about, links to that specific page, links to the overall domain, etc. Those are the biggest things that matter.

elements.text: Completely ignore Ubersuggest. It's worthless since it was acquired and (hot take) is just there to acquire links and be a personal brand tool.
What's the blog? Happy to do a quick screenshot from Ahrefs or SEMrush for ya.

LOTS of things make it perform better is search: the content on the page, the topic you're writing about, links to that specific page, links to the overall domain, etc. Those are the biggest things that matter.

text: Just as Sean mentioned, the point is not only to get traffic to your site but building an audience and putting your brand out there for the relevant audience to find. And there is no harm if you share relevant (to the industry) news and updates. Provided that you dont overdo it, I believe you can find out a lot of interesting things about your audience with that method.

elements.text: Just as Sean mentioned, the point is not only to get traffic to your site but building an audience and putting your brand out there for the relevant audience to find. text:
<@UL4QTFQCT> - I'm not sure they are. They're mostly built around the idea of what the audience would find interesting. The focus is on quality and information, less on keywords. What would you suggest?

<@UUXMCJQ15> - Thanks Brendan, that's very helpful. This is the blog - <https://mages.edu.sg/blog>
If you have a minute, would you mind looking at one of them and giving your thoughts on the factors you mentioned? I believe the content is good because I'm writing it from expertise in the industry. The images are bad because the client chooses them randomly. For msot blogs last year, the images were completely irrelevant and from student projects.

They do have links to their domain but I believe they're from cheap blackhat tactics, not genuine ones.

text: Thanks <@UUXMCJQ15> - I do understand that, however is it a waste of quality content if the chosen topic doesn't really have any search volume? Which could be verified through keyword research? I'm wondering because those who do use keyword research to find "High volume low competition" keywords make it sound like an exact science. Like a surefire way to make a blog work.

text: No. Content does a lot more things than just SEO. :slightly_smiling_face: I say that as somebody who works professionally in SEO and has had to mature into that understanding thanks to articles like this from <@UJ3K7N8GJ> <https://www.animalz.co/blog/diversified-content-portfolio/>

text: But I totally hear you. Also low volume can be a GREAT thing because it's super 'bottom of funnel' and the conversion intent is very high.

text: I'm literally teaching my team about this right now so it's very top of mind for me. There is no surefire way to make a blog work, especially not on the cheap. You can use all the tools and get Ahrefs and Marketmuse or Clearscope and optimize for entities and keywords and then get a bunch of links to it and it still may not "work."

elements.text: I'm literally teaching my team about this right now so it's very top of mind for me. There is no surefire way to make a blog work, especially not on the cheap. You can use all the tools and get Ahrefs and Marketmuse or Clearscope and optimize for entities and keywords and then get a bunch of links to it and it still may not "work."

text: But to start, I think focusing it on a topic people are searching for is the move. You can use Google's auto-complete feature or <http://Answerthepublic.com|Answerthepublic.com> to get that info.

elements.text: But to start, I think focusing it on a topic people are searching for is the move. You can use Google's auto-complete feature or

text:
Thanks Brendan, super helpful :slightly_smiling_face: I guess that brings me to another long-time problem, which is then attributing results to content. SEO and page views are easy to see and judge. Thought leadership, conversions at the bottom of the funnel are a bit harder. Especially since this client doesn't understand internet marketing and funnels that well. Really helpful hearing your thoughts though.

I've checked out answerthepublic a few times but I think I should try it out again.

elements.text: Thanks Brendan, super helpful

text: Basically you can pop in a few competitors and it'll show you the domains that link to both of them but not you. Those are typically the easiest sites to earn links from :)

text: Yeah, depending on what the links are! The easiest cases are directory-type sites with do-follow links, or best-of articles/listicles that share a bunch of similar companies. Other times it'll be richer content opportunities. But it's definitely a "warmer" backlink reachout list if they're already talking about more than one of your competitors.

elements.text: Yeah, depending on what the links are! The easiest cases are directory-type sites with do-follow links, or best-of articles/listicles that share a bunch of similar companies. Other times it'll be richer content opportunities. But it's definitely a "warmer" backlink reachout list if they're already talking about more than one of your competitors.

text: I agree with the points above! When we started our newsletter, we wanted to establish ourselves as thought leaders and the go-to in our space. For us that meant providing value and useful content to build trust in us as the experts. We have a section for "what we're reading" full of curated third-party content then at the bottom a "what we're thinking about" which is a single piece of our own content. Strikes a good balance for us.

text: Depends on the content! If it's like, "Hey, I see you mention X and Y. We also offer..." that can work. I've had people outreach to me in that way with content already pre-written to add to the post and I was willing to add it in exchange for a link from them :slightly_smiling_face:
